    getMapResponseString

    public java.lang.String getMapResponseString()
    Returns the last map response in XML format. Before each map request is sent to the MapViewer service, the previous map response string is set to null. The response string may contain a valid xml Map response, or an exception/error thrown by MapViewer. It could also be null if the map request specified the map image format to be "FORMAT_RAW_COMPRESSED".

    run

    public boolean run()
            throws java.lang.Exception
    Sends the current map request to the MapViewer mid-tier service, and obtains a map response as sent back by the MapViewer service.

    Returns:
    true if the request was successfully processed; otherwise false
    Throws:
    an - exception if the network connection encounters some problem
    java.lang.Exception

    sendXMLRequest

    public void sendXMLRequest(java.lang.String req)
                    throws java.lang.Exception
    A convenient method that lets you send any XML map or administrative request to MapViewer service. You are responsible for formulating a valid XML request. Check MapViewer User's Guide for detailed description of the MapViewer XML API.
    The request parameter will be converted into a HTTP safe string before being sent to MapViewer service. Always call getXMLResponse() after each sendXMLRequest() call, even if you are not interested in the response. If you do not call getXMLResponse() the request may not actually reach the MapViewer service.
    Use the getXMLResponse() to get the XML response string from MapViewer service. Note that if the response does not return XML document then the consequence of calling getXMLResponse() is not defined.

    Note: do not prefix your request string with "xml_request=".

    Parameters:
    req - the well-formed and valid XML request string.
    Throws:
    java.lang.Exception
    See Also:
    getXMLResponse()

    getXMLResponse

    public java.lang.String getXMLResponse()
                                throws java.lang.Exception
    After a sendXMLRequest() call, use this method to retrive the corresponding XML response from MapViewer service.
    Note that if the response does not contain a XML document then the consequence of calling this method is not defined.

    Returns:
    an XML document string sent back by MapViewer service
    Throws:
    java.lang.Exception
    See Also:
    sendXMLRequest(java.lang.String)

    drawLiveFeatures

    public void drawLiveFeatures(java.awt.Graphics2D g2,
                             java.awt.Color stroke,
                             java.awt.Color fill,
                             double pointRadius,
                             double strokeWidth)
    Draws all the live features that are returned to this client from MapViewer. The caller must provide a graphics context and the stroke color or fill color or both (that is, either the stroke color or fill color, but not both, can be null).

    If the live features are points, the pointRadius value is considered when drawing each point as a circle; for other types of live features, this parameter is ignored.

    When a feature needs to be stroked, the strokeWidth value specifies how wide the pen is when drawing the boundaries.

    Parameters:
    g - the graphics context where to draw the features.
    stroke - the stroking color for feature boundary
    fill - the filling color for feature interior
    pointRadius - if the feature is a point, it is rendered as a circle with a radius of this parameter's value
    strokeWidth - the pen width (in device units) for the feature boundary

                              int y,

    fill - the filling color for feature interior
    pointRadius - if the feature is a point, it is rendered as a circle with a radius of this parameter's value
    strokeWidth - the pen width (in device units) for the feature boundary

    addImageMarkerStyleFromURL

    public void addImageMarkerStyleFromURL(java.lang.String styleName,
                                       java.lang.String imgURL,
                                       int desiredWidth,
                                       int desiredHeight,
                                       java.lang.String fontName,
                                       int fontSize,
                                       java.lang.String fontStyle,
                                       java.lang.String fontWeight,
                                       java.lang.String fontColor)
                                throws java.lang.Exception
    Adds a GIF image as a Marker symbol to this MapViewer client. The style will be created temporarily at the server side when processing next map request. This is the more flexible version of the above method. It lets you specify not only the image of the marker, but also the desirable width/height of the image when applied to features on a map, as well as the font properties of any text label that will go inside (or on top) of the marker.

    Parameters:
    styleName - name of the marker style to be added
    imgURL - where to load the marker image
    desiredWidth - desriable width of the marker when applied on map
    desiredHeight - desirable height of the marker when applied on map
    fontName - the name or family of the font
    fontSize - the point size of the font
    fontStyle - must be "PLAIN" or "ITALIC"
    fontWeight - must be "PLAIN" or "BOLD"
    fontColor - the color of the font
    Throws:
    java.lang.Exception

    styleName - the name of the new dynamic style
    imgURL - where the pattern image is located
    strokeColor - if not null, specifies the stroking color for boundries
    strokeWidth - the widht of the stroke when draing boundaries
    storkeOpacity - the opacity of the stroking color. Must be within the range of 0-255, 0 meaning completely transparent, 255 completely opaque.
    Throws:
    java.lang.Exception

    addImageAreaStyleFromURL

    public void addImageAreaStyleFromURL(java.lang.String styleName,
                                     java.lang.String imgURL,
                                     java.lang.String lineStyle)
                              throws java.lang.Exception
    Adds a GIF or JPEG image as an Area symbol to the client. The style will be created temporarily at the server side when processing next map request. You can also specify an optional boundary style (a LINE type style) with this method.

    Parameters:
    styleName - the name of the new dynamic style
    imgURL - where the pattern image is located
    lineStyle - the name of an existing LINE style to draw the area boundary
    Throws:
    java.lang.Exception

    addColorStyle

    public void addColorStyle(java.lang.String name,
                          java.lang.String stroke,
                          java.lang.String fill,
                          int strokeOpacity,
                          int fillOpacity)
                   throws java.lang.Exception
    Adds a color style with the given parameters. The style will be created temporarily at the server side when processing next map request.

    Parameters:
    name - the name of the new style
    stroke - the color used for stroking or drawing edges. Must be a valid Java color name such as "red", "blue", or RGB hex-string such as "#ff0000".
    fill - the color used for filling geometries. Must be a valid Java color name such as "red", "blue", or RGB hex-string such as "#ff0000".
    strokeOpacity - the opacity value for the stroking color; Must within the range of 0-255, 0 meaning completely transparent, 255 completely opaque.
    fillOpacity - the opacity value for the filling color; Must within the range of 0-255, 0 meaning completely transparent, 255 completely opaque.
    Throws:
    java.lang.Exception

    addColorStyle

    public void addColorStyle(java.lang.String name,
                          java.lang.String stroke,
                          java.lang.String fill,
                          int strokeOpacity,
                          int fillOpacity,
                          java.lang.String strokeWidth)
                   throws java.lang.Exception
    Adds a color style with the given parameters. The style will be created temporarily at the server side when processing next map request.

    Parameters:
    name - the name of the new style
    stroke - the color used for stroking or drawing edges. Must be a valid Java color name such as "red", "blue", or RGB hex-string such as "#ff0000".
    fill - the color used for filling geometries. Must be a valid Java color name such as "red", "blue", or RGB hex-string such as "#ff0000".
    strokeOpacity - the opacity value for the stroking color; Must within the range of 0-255, 0 meaning completely transparent, 255 completely opaque.
    fillOpacity - the opacity value for the filling color; Must within the range of 0-255, 0 meaning completely transparent, 255 completely opaque.
    strokeWidth - a string containing the stroke width to be used, such as "2.5".
    Throws:
    java.lang.Exception

    addMarkerStyle

    public void addMarkerStyle(java.lang.String name,
                           int mktype,
                           java.lang.String strokeColor,
                           java.lang.String fillColor,
                           java.lang.String markerWidth,
                           java.lang.String markerHeight,
                           java.lang.String coords,
                           java.lang.String radius)
                    throws java.lang.Exception
    Adds a vector marker style with the given parameters. The style will be created temporarily at the server side when processing next map request. Marker types: MARKER_POLYGON, MARKER_POLYLINE, MARKER_CIRCLE, MARKER_RECT Java example: 
           mapViewer.addMarkerStyle("mkpolygon",1,"blue","red","15","15","100,20,40,50,60,80,100,20",null);  
       mapViewer.addMarkerStyle("mkpolyline",2,"blue","red","5","5","100,20,120,40,140,20,120,0",null);     
       mapViewer.addMarkerStyle("mkcircle", 3, "blue","red",null,null,null,"5");
       mapViewer.addMarkerStyle("mkrect",4,"blue","red","5","5","0,0,120,120",null);

    Parameters:
    name - the name of the new style
    mktype - the marker type
    strokeColor - stroke color value
    fillColor - fill color value
    markerWidth - marker width (null for circle)
    markerHeight - marker height (null for circle)
    coords - the coordinates that define the vector marker (null for circle).
    radius - used for marker of type "circle".
    Throws:
    java.lang.Exception

    addCollectionBucketStyle

    public void addCollectionBucketStyle(java.lang.String name,
                                     java.lang.String[] label,
                                     java.lang.String[] styleName,
                                     java.lang.String[][] value)
                              throws java.lang.Exception
    Adds a collection bucket style with the given parameters. The style will be created temporarily at the server side when processing next map request. All bucket styles must have been previously added on MapViewer. Java example: 
           String []states = {"California","Utah","Texas","Nevada","Oregon",
                          "Montana","Washinton","Idaho","New Mexico",
                          "Arizona","Wyoming","Colorado"};

       String []ststyles = {"colorblue","colorgreen","coloryellow","colorpink",
                            "colororange","colorblack","colorred","colorwhite",
                            "colormagenta","colorgray","colorltgray","colorcyan" };

      String [][]values = new String[12][];
      for(int i=0;i<12;i++)
        values[i] = new String[1];

      values[0][0]= "California";
      values[1][0] = "Utah";
      values[2][0] = "Texas";
      values[3][0] = "Nevada";
      values[4][0] = "Oregon";
      values[5][0] = "Montana";
      values[6][0] = "Washington";
      values[7][0] = "Idaho";
      values[8][0] = "New Mexico";
      values[9][0] = "Arizona";
      values[10][0] = "Wyoming";
      values[11][0] = "Colorado";

      mapViewer.addCollectionBucketStyle("collbucket", states, ststyles, values);
      mapViewer.addJDBCTheme("tilsmenv","county_th","select geom, state from counties","geom",
                              "8265","collbucket",null,null,false);

    Parameters:
    name - the name of the new style
    labels - the bucket labels.
    styleNames - the styles associated with each bucket.
    values - the attribute values associated with each bucket
    Throws:
    java.lang.Exception

    addRangedBucketStyle

    public void addRangedBucketStyle(java.lang.String name,
                                 java.lang.String[] label,
                                 java.lang.String[] low,
                                 java.lang.String[] high,
                                 java.lang.String[] styleName)
                          throws java.lang.Exception
    Adds a ranged bucket style (not necessarily equal intervals) with the given parameters. The style will be created temporarily at the server side when processing next map request. All bucket styles must have been previously added on MapViewer or exists as permanent styles. Java example: 
           String []labels = {"less than 100k","100k - 150k","150k - 250k","250k - 350k","350k - 450k"};

       String []low =  new String[5];
       low[0] = null;
       low[1] = "100000.0";
       low[2] = "150000.0";
       low[3] = "250000.0";
       low[4] = "350000.0";

       String []high = new String[5];
       high[0] = "100000.0";
       high[1] = "150000.0";
       high[2] = "250000.0";
       high[3] = "350000.0";
       high[4] = "450000.0";

       String []styles = new String[5];
       styles[0] = "colorblue";
       styles[1] = "colorgreen";  
       styles[2] = "coloryellow";
       styles[3] = "colorpink";
       styles[4] = "colororange";

       mapViewer.addRangedBucketStyle("rangedbkstyle",labels,low,high,styles);
       mapViewer.addJDBCTheme("tilsmenv","county_th","select geom, totpop from counties","geom",
                            "8265","rangedbkstyle",null,null,false);

    Parameters:
    name - the name of the new style
    label - bucket label
    low - the low range value.
    high - the high range value.
    styleName - the style names for each bucket
    Throws:
    java.lang.Exception

    addRangedBucketStyle

    public void addRangedBucketStyle(java.lang.String name,
                                 java.lang.String[] label,
                                 java.lang.String[] low,
                                 java.lang.String[] high,
                                 java.lang.String[] styleName,
                                 java.lang.String defaultStyle)
                          throws java.lang.Exception
    Adds a ranged bucket style (not necessarily equal intervals) with the given parameters. Same as the above method, except that this method lets you specify a default style. Java example: 
           String []labels = {"less than 100k","100k - 150k","150k - 250k","250k - 350k","350k - 450k"};

       String []low =  new String[5];
       low[0] = null;
       low[1] = "100000.0";
       low[2] = "150000.0";
       low[3] = "250000.0";
       low[4] = "350000.0";

       String []high = new String[5];
       high[0] = "100000.0";
       high[1] = "150000.0";
       high[2] = "250000.0";
       high[3] = "350000.0";
       high[4] = "450000.0";

       String []styles = new String[5];
       styles[0] = "colorblue";
       styles[1] = "colorgreen";  
       styles[2] = "coloryellow";
       styles[3] = "colorpink";
       styles[4] = "colororange";

       mapViewer.addRangedBucketStyle("rangedbkstyle",labels,low,high,styles);
       mapViewer.addJDBCTheme("tilsmenv","county_th","select geom, totpop from counties","geom",
                            "8265","rangedbkstyle",null,null,false);

    Parameters:
    name - the name of the new style
    label - bucket label
    low - the low range value.
    high - the high range value.
    styleName - the style names for each bucket
    defaultStyle - the default style to use if none of the buckets contain a given attribute value.
    Throws:
    java.lang.Exception

    addBucketStyle

    public void addBucketStyle(java.lang.String name,
                           java.lang.String low,
                           java.lang.String high,
                           int nbuckets,
                           java.lang.String[] styleName)
                    throws java.lang.Exception
    Adds an bucket style (equal intervals) with the given parameters. The style will be created temporarily at the server side when processing next map request. All bucket styles must have been previously added on MapViewer or exist as permanent styles. Java example: 
           String []styles = new String[5];
       styles[0] = "colorblue";
       styles[1] = "colorgreen";  
       styles[2] = "coloryellow";
       styles[3] = "colorpink";
       styles[4] = "colororange";
       mapViewer.addBucketStyle("equalbucket","0.0","450000.",5,styles);
       mapViewer.addJDBCTheme("tilsmenv","county_th","select geom, totpop from counties","geom",
                           "8265","equalbucket",null,null,false);

    Parameters:
    name - the name of the new style
    nbuckets - number of buckets
    low - the low range value.
    high - the high range value.
    styleName - the style names for each bucket
    Throws:
    java.lang.Exception

    addVariableMarkerStyle

    public void addVariableMarkerStyle(java.lang.String name,
                                   java.lang.String[] label,
                                   java.lang.String baseMarker,
                                   int startSize,
                                   int increment,
                                   java.lang.String[] low,
                                   java.lang.String[] high)
                            throws java.lang.Exception
    Adds a variable marker style with the given parameters. The style will be created temporarily at the server side when processing next map request. Note: When adding a JDBC theme to a MapViewer service, add a dummy column on the select statement. This 'dummy' column will be the label column. Java example: 
           mapViewer.addColorStyle("colorst", "blue","red", 100, 100);
       mapViewer.addMarkerStyle("mkcircle", 3, "blue","red",null,null,null,"5");

       String []labelsvm = {"less than 100k","100k - 150k","150k - 250k",
                           "250k - 350k","350k - 450k",
                           "450k - 1000K","over 1000K"};

      String []lowvm =  new String[7];   // low values
      lowvm[0] = null;
      lowvm[1] = "100000.0";
      lowvm[2] = "150000.0";
      lowvm[3] = "250000.0";
      lowvm[4] = "350000.0";
      lowvm[5] = "450000.0";
      lowvm[6] = "1000000.0";

      String []highvm = new String[7];  // high values
      highvm[0] = "100000.0";
      highvm[1] = "150000.0";
      highvm[2] = "250000.0";
      highvm[3] = "350000.0";
      highvm[4] = "450000.0";
      highvm[5] = "1000000.0";
      highvm[6] = "9000000.0";

      mapViewer.addVariableMarkerStyle("varmarker", labelsvm, "mkcircle", 5,3,
                                       lowvm, highvm);
      mapViewer.addJDBCTheme("tilsmenv","county_th","select geom,'dummy' dummy,
                             totpop from counties","geom",
                             "8265","colorst","dummy","varmarker",false);

    Parameters:
    name - the name of the new style
    label - the label name
    low - the low range value.
    high - the high range value.
    Throws:
    java.lang.Exception

    addVariableMarkerStyle

    public void addVariableMarkerStyle(java.lang.String name,
                                   java.lang.String[] label,
                                   java.lang.String baseMarker,
                                   int startSize,
                                   int increment,
                                   java.lang.String[] low,
                                   java.lang.String[] high,
                                   java.lang.String defaultStyle)
                            throws java.lang.Exception
    Adds a variable marker style with the given parameters. This method is the same as the above, except you can provide a default (primitive) style to be used when MapViewer cannot determine which bucket a value falls into. Note: When adding a JDBC theme to a MapViewer service, add a dummy column on the select statement. This 'dummy' column will be the label column. Java example: 
           mapViewer.addColorStyle("colorst", "blue","red", 100, 100);
       mapViewer.addMarkerStyle("mkcircle", 3, "blue","red",null,null,null,"5");

       String []labelsvm = {"less than 100k","100k - 150k","150k - 250k",
                           "250k - 350k","350k - 450k",
                           "450k - 1000K","over 1000K"};

      String []lowvm =  new String[7];   // low values
      lowvm[0] = null;
      lowvm[1] = "100000.0";
      lowvm[2] = "150000.0";
      lowvm[3] = "250000.0";
      lowvm[4] = "350000.0";
      lowvm[5] = "450000.0";
      lowvm[6] = "1000000.0";

      String []highvm = new String[7];  // high values
      highvm[0] = "100000.0";
      highvm[1] = "150000.0";
      highvm[2] = "250000.0";
      highvm[3] = "350000.0";
      highvm[4] = "450000.0";
      highvm[5] = "1000000.0";
      highvm[6] = "9000000.0";

      mapViewer.addVariableMarkerStyle("varmarker", labelsvm, "mkcircle", 5,3,
                                       lowvm, highvm);
      mapViewer.addJDBCTheme("tilsmenv","county_th","select geom,'dummy' dummy,
                             totpop from counties","geom",
                             "8265","colorst","dummy","varmarker",false);

    Parameters:
    name - the name of the new style
    label - the label name
    low - the low range value.
    high - the high range value.
    defaultStyle - the name fo the defulat style to use; specify null if you do not wish to use a default style.
    Throws:
    java.lang.Exception

    addTextStyle

    public void addTextStyle(java.lang.String name,
                         java.lang.String style,
                         java.lang.String family,
                         java.lang.String size,
                         java.lang.String weight,
                         java.lang.String fill)
                  throws java.lang.Exception
    Adds a text style with the given parameters. The style will be created temporarily at the server side when processing next map request. Java example: 
           mapViewer.addTextStyle("textstyle","plain","Dialog","14pt","bold","blue");

    Parameters:

    style - the font style ("plain", "italic", "bold")
    family - the font family

    addTextStyleWithHalo

    public void addTextStyleWithHalo(java.lang.String name,
                                 java.lang.String style,
                                 java.lang.String family,
                                 java.lang.String size,
                                 java.lang.String weight,
                                 java.lang.String fill,
                                 double haloWidth)
    Adds a text style with the given parameters. The text rendered using this style will have a white halo surrounding each character. The style will be created temporarily at the server side when processing next map request. Java example: 
           mapViewer.addTextStyle("textstyle","plain","Dialog","14pt","bold","blue", 2.5);

    Parameters:
    name - the name of the new style
    style - the font style ("plain", "italic", "bold")
    family - the font family
    size - the font size (for example "14pt")
    weight - the font weight
    fill - the font color
    haloWidth - the width or thickness of the white halo, in pixel

    addLineStyle

    public void addLineStyle(java.lang.String name,
                         java.lang.String fill,
                         java.lang.String strokeWidth,
                         boolean hasBase,
                         java.lang.String baseFill,
                         java.lang.String baseStroke,
                         java.lang.String baseDash,
                         boolean hasParallel,
                         java.lang.String fillParallel,
                         java.lang.String strokeParallel,
                         boolean hasHashMark,
                         java.lang.String fillHash,
                         java.lang.String dashHash)
                  throws java.lang.Exception
    Adds a line style with the given parameters. The style will be created temporarily at the server side when processing next map request. At least one of the line styles must be defined: base, parallel or hashmark line parameters. Java example: 
           mapViewer.addLineStyle("highwayline","#33a9ff","4",false,null,null,null,
                              true,"red","1.0",false,null,null);
       mapViewer.addLineStyle("fullline","#ffff00","5",true,"black","1.0","10.0,4.0",
                              true,"#ff0000","1.0",true,"#003333","8.5,3.0");
       mapViewer.addLineStyle("stateline","#ffff66","7",true,"#000000","1.0","1.0,4.0",
                              false,null,null,false,null,null);

      mapViewer.addJDBCTheme("tilsmenv","highway_th","select geom from interstates","geom",
                             "8265","highwayline",null,null,false);
      mapViewer.addJDBCTheme("tilsmenv","statesline_th","select geom from states","geom",
                             "8265","stateline",null,null,false);

    Parameters:
    name - the name of the new style
    fill - line fill style
    stroke_width - line stroke width
    hasBase - indicates if there is a base line definition
    baseFill - fill style of base line
    baseStroke - stroke width style of base line
    baseDash - dash style of base line
    hasParallel - indicates if there is a parallel line definition
    fillParallel - fill style of parallel line
    strokeParallel - stroke width style of parallel line
    hasHashMark - indicates if there is a hash mark definition
    fillHash - fill style for hash mark
    dashHash - dash style for hash mark
    Throws:
    java.lang.Exception

    addLineStyle

    public void addLineStyle(java.lang.String name,
                         java.lang.String fill,
                         java.lang.String strokeWidth,
                         boolean hasBase,
                         java.lang.String baseFill,
                         java.lang.String baseStroke,
                         java.lang.String baseDash,
                         boolean hasParallel,
                         java.lang.String fillParallel,
                         java.lang.String strokeParallel,
                         boolean hasHashMark,
                         java.lang.String fillHash,
                         java.lang.String dashHash,
                         java.lang.String measureMarker,
                         double measurePosition,
                         int measureSize)
                  throws java.lang.Exception
    Similar to the previous addLinestyle method, with the addition of measure marker parameters. These paramaters will result on a direction marker at the specified position of the line. The direction will be rendered following the orientation of the line segment in which the marker position falls.

    Parameters:
    name - the name of the new style
    fill - line fill style
    stroke_width - line stroke width
    hasBase - indicates if there is a base line definition
    baseFill - fill style of base line
    baseStroke - stroke width style of base line
    baseDash - dash style of base line
    hasParallel - indicates if there is a parallel line definition
    fillParallel - fill style of parallel line
    strokeParallel - stroke width style of parallel line
    hasHashMark - indicates if there is a hash mark definition
    fillHash - fill style for hash mark
    dashHash - dash style for hash mark
    measureMarker - marker style name to represent direction
    measurePosition - position [0.,1.] on the line to render the direction marker
    measureSize - defines the direction marker size
    Throws:
    java.lang.Exception

    setMapLegend

    public void setMapLegend(java.lang.String fill,
                         java.lang.String fillopacity,
                         java.lang.String stroke,
                         java.lang.String profile,
                         java.lang.String position,
                         java.lang.String[][][] legenddata)
    Sets the map request legend, that is translated into a XML expression to be sent to the server. The XML expression is such as: 
          <legend bgstyle="fill:#ffffff;fill-opacity:128;stroke:#ff0000" 
                profile="MEDIUM" position="SOUTH_EAST">
         <column>
          <entry text="Map Legend" is_title="true" />
          <entry style="M.STAR" text="center point" />
          <entry style="M.CITY HALL 3" text="cities" />
          <entry is_separator="true" />
          <entry style="C.ROSY BROWN STROKE" text="state boundary" />
          <entry style="L.PH" text="interstate highway" />
          <entry text="County population:" />
          <entry style="V.COUNTY_POP_DENSITY" tab="1" />
        </column>
     </legend>
    Java example: 
      
       String [][][]legenddata = new String[1][][];  // legend with one column
       legenddata[0] = new String[8][];    // column with 8 items
       for(int i=0;i<8;i++)
       {
         legenddata[0][i] = new String[5];   // description of each item
         legenddata[0][i][0] = null;      // text
         legenddata[0][i][1] = null;      // style
         legenddata[0][i][2] = "false";   // is title
         legenddata[0][i][3] = null;      // tab
         legenddata[0][i][4] = "false";   // is separator
       }

       // <entry text="Map Legend" is_title="true" />
       legenddata[0][0][0] = "Map Legend"; // text
       legenddata[0][0][2] = "true";       // is title

       // <entry style="M.STAR" text="center point" />
       legenddata[0][1][0] = "center point";  // text
       legenddata[0][1][1] = "M.STAR";        // style

       // <entry style="M.CITY HALL 3" text="cities" />
       legenddata[0][2][0] = "cities";        // text
       legenddata[0][2][1] = "M.CITY HALL";   // style

       // <entry is_separator="true" />
       legenddata[0][3][4] = "true";          // is separator

       // <entry style="C.ROSY BROWN STROKE" text="state boundary" />
       legenddata[0][4][0] = "state boundary";         // text
       legenddata[0][4][1] = "C.ROSY BROWN STROKE";    // style

       // <entry style="L.PH" text="interstate highway" />
       legenddata[0][5][0] = "interstate highway";    // text
       legenddata[0][5][1] = "L.PH";                  // style

       // <entry text="County population:" />
       legenddata[0][6][0] = "County population:";    // text

       // <entry style="V.COUNTY_POP_DENSITY" tab="1" />
       legenddata[0][7][1] = "V.COUNTY_POP_DENSITY";  // style
       legenddata[0][7][3] = "1";                     // tab    

       mapViewer.setMapLegend("#ffffff","255","#ff0000","MEDIUM",
                              "NORTH_EAST",legenddata);

    Parameters:
    fill - the color used for filling the background. Must be a valid Java color name such as "red", "blue", or RGB hex-string such as "#ff0000".
    fillopacity - the opacity value (0-255).
    stroke - the color used for stroking the legend background. Must be a valid Java color name such as "red", "blue", or RGB hex-string such as "#ff0000".
    profile - the size profile of the legend ("SMALL", "MEDIUM" or "LARGE")
    position - where to place the legend inside the map image
    legenddata - describe the legend items. If null, MapViewer will generate an automatic legend with styles from themes that have any interaction with the query window. Each column will have a maximum of 5 styles. The variable structure is: 
              String [x][y][z] where:
              // x - number of legend columns
              // y - number of column itens
              // z - legend attributes (equal 5)
                     // index 0 - text
                     // index 1 - style
                     // index 2 - is title
                     // index 3 - tab
                     // index 4 - is separator

    setMapLegend

    public void setMapLegend(java.lang.String fill,
                         java.lang.String fillopacity,
                         java.lang.String stroke,
                         java.lang.String profile,
                         java.lang.String position,
                         java.lang.String fontFamily,
                         java.lang.String[][][] legenddata)
    Same as the above method, except this one also lets you specify the font family name for the legend texts.

    Parameters:
    fill - the color used for filling the background. Must be a valid Java color name such as "red", "blue", or RGB hex-string such as "#ff0000".
    fillopacity - the opacity value (0-255).
    stroke - the color used for stroking the legend background. Must be a valid Java color name such as "red", "blue", or RGB hex-string such as "#ff0000".
    profile - the size profile of the legend ("SMALL", "MEDIUM" or "LARGE")
    position - where to place the legend inside the map image
    fontFamily - the font family name to be used by the legend text
    legenddata - describe the legend items. If null, MapViewer will generate an automatic legend with styles from themes that have any interaction with the query window. Each column will have a maximum of 5 styles. The variable structure is: 
              String [x][y][z] where:
              // x - number of legend columns
              // y - number of column itens
              // z - legend attributes (equal 5)
                     // index 0 - text
                     // index 1 - style
                     // index 2 - is title
                     // index 3 - tab
                     // index 4 - is separator

    setMapLegend

    public void setMapLegend(java.lang.String fill,
                         java.lang.String fillopacity,
                         java.lang.String stroke,
                         java.lang.String profile,
                         java.lang.String position,
                         int offset_x,
                         int offset_y,
                         java.lang.String fontFamily,
                         java.lang.String[][][] legenddata)
    Same as the above method, except this one also lets you specify the position offset.

    Parameters:
    fill - the color used for filling the background. Must be a valid Java color name such as "red", "blue", or RGB hex-string such as "#ff0000".
    fillopacity - the opacity value (0-255).
    stroke - the color used for stroking the legend background. Must be a valid Java color name such as "red", "blue", or RGB hex-string such as "#ff0000".
    profile - the size profile of the legend ("SMALL", "MEDIUM" or "LARGE")
    position - where to place the legend inside the map image
    offset_x - X offset from the border to be applied on position (use positive value)
    offset_y - Y offset from the border to be applied on position (use positive value)
    fontFamily - the font family name to be used by the legend text
    legenddata - describe the legend items. If null, MapViewer will generate an automatic legend with styles from themes that have any interaction with the query window. Each column will have a maximum of 5 styles. The variable structure is: 
              String [x][y][z] where:
              // x - number of legend columns
              // y - number of column itens
              // z - legend attributes (equal 5)
                     // index 0 - text
                     // index 1 - style
                     // index 2 - is title
                     // index 3 - tab
                     // index 4 - is separator

    setMapLegend

    public void setMapLegend(java.lang.String fill,
                         java.lang.String fillopacity,
                         java.lang.String stroke,
                         java.lang.String profile,
                         int location_x,
                         int location_y,
                         java.lang.String fontFamily,

    fillopacity - the opacity value (0-255).

    profile - the size profile of the legend ("SMALL", "MEDIUM" or "LARGE")
    location_x - X position in screen unit.
    location_y - Y position in screen unit.
    fontFamily - the font family name to be used by the legend text
    legenddata - describe the legend items. If null, MapViewer will generate an automatic legend with styles from themes that have any interaction with the query window. Each column will have a maximum of 5 styles. The variable structure is: 
              String [x][y][z] where:
              // x - number of legend columns
              // y - number of column itens
              // z - legend attributes (equal 5)
                     // index 0 - text
                     // index 1 - style
                     // index 2 - is title
                     // index 3 - tab
                     // index 4 - is separator

    setMapLegendFromThemes

    public void setMapLegendFromThemes(java.lang.String fill,
                                   java.lang.String fillopacity,
                                   java.lang.String stroke,
                                   java.lang.String profile,
                                   java.lang.String position,
                                   int offset_x,
                                   int offset_y,
                                   java.lang.String fontFamily,
                                   java.lang.String[] themeNames)
    Sets the map request legend with theme names defined, that is translated into a XML expression to be sent to the server. MapViewer will build a legend with the rendering and labeling styles of the themes. Each legend column will have a maximum of 5 styles. The XML expression is such as: 
          <legend bgstyle="fill:#ffffff;fill-opacity:128;stroke:#ff0000" 
                profile="MEDIUM" position="SOUTH_EAST">
         <themes>
          <theme name="theme_1" />
          <theme name="theme_2" />
        </themes>
     </legend>

    Parameters:
    fill - the color used for filling the background. Must be a valid Java color name such as "red", "blue", or RGB hex-string such as "#ff0000".
    fillopacity - the opacity value (0-255).
    stroke - the color used for stroking the legend background. Must be a valid Java color name such as "red", "blue", or RGB hex-string such as "#ff0000".
    profile - the size profile of the legend ("SMALL", "MEDIUM" or "LARGE")
    position - where to place the legend inside the map image
    offset_x - X offset from the border to be applied on position (use positive value)
    offset_y - Y offset from the border to be applied on position (use positive value)
    fontFamily - the font family name to be used by the legend text
    themeNames - the theme names to retrieve the rendering and labeling styles to build the legend. If null, MapViewer will generate an automatic legend with styles from themes that have any interaction with the query window. Each column will have a maximum of 5 styles.

    setMapLegendFromThemes

    public void setMapLegendFromThemes(java.lang.String fill,
                                   java.lang.String fillopacity,
                                   java.lang.String stroke,
                                   java.lang.String profile,
                                   int location_x,
                                   int location_y,
                                   java.lang.String fontFamily,
                                   java.lang.String[] themeNames)
    Same as the above method, except this one lets you specify the location of the legend instead of using the location hint.

    Parameters:
    fill - the color used for filling the background. Must be a valid Java color name such as "red", "blue", or RGB hex-string such as "#ff0000".
    fillopacity - the opacity value (0-255).
    stroke - the color used for stroking the legend background. Must be a valid Java color name such as "red", "blue", or RGB hex-string such as "#ff0000".
    profile - the size profile of the legend ("SMALL", "MEDIUM" or "LARGE")
    location_x - X position in screen unit.
    location_y - Y position in screen unit.
    fontFamily - the font family name to be used by the legend text
    themeNames - the theme names to retrieve the rendering and labeling styles to build the legend. If null, MapViewer will generate an automatic legend with styles from themes that have any interaction with the query window. Each column will have a maximum of 5 styles.

    deleteMapLegend

    public void deleteMapLegend()
    This method removes the legend from the map request.

    setMapRequestSRID

    public void setMapRequestSRID(int id)
    Sets the map request SRID. This will be the master or target SRID of the map being generated. If a non-zero srid is specified, and if it is different from the srid of the underlying user data, then MapViewer will do on-the-fly coordinate transformation of the user's spatial data into this target srid.

    Parameters:
    id - spatial reference id.

    Gets the map request SRID.

    setSVGOnClick

    public void setSVGOnClick(java.lang.String onClick)

    getThemeAsHTMLAreas

    public java.lang.String getThemeAsHTMLAreas(java.lang.String themeName,
                                            boolean renderPointAsCircle)
    Return html area definition of the given theme. The html AREA definition can be used with html MAP to enable client side interactivity on regular image maps. 
        <map name="mymap">
      <area 
       shape="POLY" 
       coord="10,20,30,15,45,70,10,20" 
       onmouseover="showInfo('info tip')" 
       onmouseout="hideInfo()" 
       onmouseclick="areaClicked(event, 'info tip')">
      ...
    </map>
    <img src="images/omsmap123.gif" usemap="#mymap"/>
    The valid shapes of html area are circle, rectangle and polygon. Therefore only themes of point or polygon type can be converted to html area definition.

    Three mouse event handling attributes of the area definition will be rendered with the area definition. They are:

    • onmouseover="showInfo(<info tip>)" onmouseover attribute specifies the javascript function to be called when the mouse move over the area. This javascript function has to be defined in the html page. And its name has to be "showInfo". A sample showInfo function is defined in mvscript.js, which can be found the mapviewer demo directory. It takes one parameter, <info tip>. <info tip> is a string of attribute/value pairs if the theme has associates info attributes. It looks like '<attr1>="<val1>" <attr2>="<val2" ...' If the theme has no associated info attributes, <info tip> will be the label string.
    • onmouseout="hideInfo()" onmouseout attribute specifies the javascript function to be called when the mouse move out of the area. This javascript function has to be defined in the html page. And its name has to be "hideInfo". A sample hideInfo function is defined in mvscript.js, which can be found the mapviewer demo directory.
    • onmouseclick="<onclick_function>(event, <info tip>)" onmouseclick attribute specifies the javascript function to be called when the mouse is clicked on the area. This javascript function has to be defined in the html page. And its name has to be "areaClicked". It takes two parameters, "event" and <info tip>.

    If the theme is a point theme, this method can converts points into circle areas or rectangle areas, which is determined by parameter renderPointAsRectangle.

    Parameters:
    themeName - the name of theme to be converted to html area definition
    renderPointAsCircle - true if the point areas are to be rendered as circles

                                          java.lang.Object value)

    Parameters:

    value - the value for the property
    Returns:

    addNSDataProvider

    public void addNSDataProvider(java.lang.String providerId,

                              java.lang.String spatialKeyColumn,
                              java.lang.String customRenderingStyle,
                              java.util.Properties params,
                              long timeout)

    getThemeModifiers

    public java.util.Hashtable getThemeModifiers()
    Returns the theme modifiers. These modifiers applies to basemap themes, and will override any basemap theme definition. Each theme modifier has a hash table with the modifier parameters.

    Returns:

    addThemeModifier

    public void addThemeModifier(java.lang.String theme,
                             java.lang.String modifier,
                             java.lang.String value)
    Adds a basemap theme modifier. This modifier will override the equivalent parameter on the basemap theme definition. The following map request contains the element that changes the label_always_on attribute for theme THEME_US_AIRPORT: 
        <?xml version="1.0" standalone="yes"?>
    <map_request
      title="Override map theme forced labeling"
      basemap="FORCED_LABELING"
      datasource="tilsmenv"
      width="500"
      height="375"
      bgcolor="#a6caf0"
      antialiase="true"
      format="PNG_STREAM">
      <center size="15.0">
        <geoFeature>
          <geometricProperty typeName="center">
            <Point>
              <coordinates>-122.4,37.8</coordinates>
            </Point>
          </geometricProperty>
        </geoFeature>
      </center>
      <theme_modifiers>
        <theme_decorations name="THEME_US_AIRPORT" label_always_on="false" />
      </theme_modifiers>
    </map_request>
    General modifiers: "label_always_on", "min_scale", "max_scale", "fast_unpickle", "reorient_lines", "minimum_pixels", "transparency" SVG modifiers: "min_dist", "fixed_svglabel", "selectable_in_svg", "onclick", "onmouseover", "onmousemove", "onmouseout" Workspace modifiers: "workspace_name", "workspace_savepoint", "workspace_date", "workspace_date_format", "workspace_date_nlsparam", "workspace_date_tswtz"

    Parameters:
    theme - theme name
    modifier - modifier name (for example "transparency")
    value - modifier value

    removeThemeModifier

    public void removeThemeModifier(java.lang.String theme,
                                java.lang.String modifier)
    Removes the theme modifier value.

    Parameters:
    theme -
    modifier -

    removeThemeModifiers

    public void removeThemeModifiers(java.lang.String theme)
    Removes the theme modifier.

    Parameters:
    theme -

    removeAllThemeModifiers

    public void removeAllThemeModifiers()
    Removes all theme modifiers.

    setUseCachedBaseMap

    public void setUseCachedBaseMap(boolean useCachedBaseMap)
    Set whether to use the cached base map. If true, MapViewer will use the base map image cached by MapCacheServer.

    Parameters:
    cache - whether to use cahced base map

    setSnapToCachedZoomLevel

    public void setSnapToCachedZoomLevel(boolean snapToCachedZoomLevel)
    Set whether to snap the map scale to match the cached zoom levels. If false, the cached base map will be used only when the map scale specified by the map request matches that of a predefined cached zoom level. If true, the cached base map will be used even when the map scale sepcified by the map request does not match any of the predefined cached zoom levels. In this case, the query window defined in the map request might be adjusted so that the map scale can match a predefined cached zoom level.

    Parameters:
    snap -

    addDotDensityStyle

    public void addDotDensityStyle(java.lang.String name,
                               int dotWidth,
                               int dotHeight,
                               java.lang.String dotMarkerStyle)
                        throws java.lang.Exception
    Adds a temporary Dot-Density style to the current map request. A Dot-Density style applies a set of fixed-size dots to each area based on some count values associated with the area.
    When adding a new Dot-Density style, the size of the dots must be specified. The shape of each dot will either be a black filled circle (the default), or that of the specified Marker style (optional).

    Parameters:
    name - name of the Dot-Density style
    dotWidth - width of each dot drawn by this style, in pixels
    dotHeight - height of each dot drawn by this style, in pixels
    dotMarkerStyle - an optional Marker style that provides the shape for the dots, or NULL if using default dot shape
    Throws:
    java.lang.Exception

    addCollectionStyle

    public void addCollectionStyle(java.lang.String name,
                               java.lang.String[] styles,
                               java.lang.String[] shapes)
                        throws java.lang.Exception
    Adds a temporary collection style to the current map request. It allows to associate different styles for different shapes.

    Parameters:
    name - new style name
    styles - styles names
    shapes - shape type (may be null, in this case style applies to all shapes)
    Throws:

    addStyle

    public void addStyle(java.lang.String name,
                     StyleModel tempStyle)
    Adds a temporary style to the current map request. The temporary style is defined by its StyleModel object, and is created at the server side when the current map request is being processed.
    This method can be used in place of all the other addStyle() methods.

    Parameters:
    name - name of the temporary style to be added
    tempStyle - the concrete style model for the temporary style to be added to the current request.

    setThemeBindingParameters

    public void setThemeBindingParameters(java.lang.String theme,
                                      java.lang.Object[] parameters)
    Sets the parameters (values) required by a predefined theme that contains custom binding variable(s). The parameters are specified via an Object array. Each element of the Object is the value for one corresponing binding variable in the theme query. In other words, parameters[0] is for the first user-specified binding variable in the theme's query, and so forth. For a list or table-type binding variable, use oracle.mapviewer.share.ArrayParameter to supply the list of values. For instance, if your theme contains a condition like this:
    (state_abrv in (select column_value from table(:1))) The corresponding object for this binding variable should be:
    ArrayParameter ap = new ArrayParameter("MV_STRINGLIST", { "MA","NY","ME","NH" }); where "MV_STRINGLIST" is a SQL list type created by MapViewer automatically. And the parameters array should be (assuming no other binding variable): Object[] parameters = new Object[] {ap};

    Parameters:
    theme - the name of a theme
    parameters - the parameters for the binding variables of the theme

    setThemeRuntimeParameters

    public void setThemeRuntimeParameters(java.lang.String theme,
                                      java.util.Properties parameters)
    Sets the runtime parameters to be used by a predefined theme (currently applies to custom geometry themes).

    Parameters:
    theme - the name of theme
    parameters - the parameter properties with names and values

    setThemeRenderLabels

    public void setThemeRenderLabels(java.lang.String theme,
                                 boolean renderLabels)
    Sets whether to render theme labels. The default value is true. It is mainly used if you want to completely turn off theme labeling, by setting its value to false. When set to false, it takes precedence over setLabelAlwaysOn even if the latter is set to true.

    Parameters:
    theme - the name of theme
    renderLables - whether to render theme labels

    setThemeFetchSize

                              int fetchSize)
    Sets the JDBC fetch size.

    Parameters:
    theme - the name of theme
    fetchSize - number of rows to be fetched.

    setThemeRenderingRules

    public void setThemeRenderingRules(java.lang.String theme,
                                   RenderingRule[][] rrules)
    Sets the theme rendering rules. Applies to dynamic geometry and topology themes. RenderingRule represents an advanced definition for using styles when rendering. Each rendering rule is defined by the following fields: a) style name: base rendering style that will define the rendering shape. b) style columns: names of the attributes to be use with base style (separated by comma) Generally used with advanced styles. c) sub-style name: sub style that will define the rendering pattern (fille color for example). d) sub-style columns: names of the attributes to be used with sub-style (separated by comma). Generally used with advanced styles. It can used in two different ways as part of the theme definition: 1) For advanced styles: A base advanced style associated with some attributes can be rendered using some properties of a sub-style, which can be based on different attributes.
    2) use multiple styles to render a feature. 
           
         
         
           
       25,50 
       16,32 
    

    

    

    

    

    

    Parameters:
    na - North Arrow

    getCookies

    public java.lang.String getCookies()
    Return previously set user cookies.

    Returns:
    A string containing previously set cookies

    setCookies

    public void setCookies(java.lang.String cookies)
    Set user supplied cookies string on the outgoing Http connection. The cookies can be used by the remote MapViewer server to associate an existing (possibly authenticated) session with the requests sent by this client. From a servlet or JSP page, you can get the cookies string using the following sample code: 
    
         Cookie[]  _cookies = request.getCookies();
         String cookies = "";
         for(int i=0; i<_cookies.length; i++)
         {
                 String name = _cookies[i].getName();
                 String value = _cookies[i].getValue();
                 cookies += name+"="+value;
                 if(i!=_cookies.length-1)
                         cookies +="; ";
         }
    Where request is an instance of HttpServletRequest. The setCookies() method should be called as soon as the MapViewer bean itself is constructed.

    Parameters:
    cookies - a string containing cookies from an existing session.
